708580f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, at the N. W. corner of West 34th Street, showing the A. T. Stewart mansion that later became the home of the Manhattan Club.

About 1870s

American Studio, photo
87 Nassau St., N. Y. C.

Gift of Urbrock Collection

708581f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, north from West 34th to 35th Street's, showing the Manhattan Club (former A. T. Stewart mansion), the Fifth Avenue Art Galleries, and the New York Club (former Caswell home that became the University Club). 34th Street is to the left of the center, while the Avenue is to the right.
March 17, 1894
Gift of Urbrock Collection
Nig. #854

708494f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, south from 34th Street. At the left is the remaining Astor home. It's former twin structure provided the site for the Hotel Waldorf shown. In the mid-background is the spire of the Marble Collegiate Church at 29th Street.

About 1898

H.N. Tiemann, photo
Gift of Urbrock Collection

708579f-a.text:
Fifth Ave., at the N.W. corner of West 34th Street, showing two identical views of the 4-story mansion of the Manhattan Club, formerly the A.T. Stewart home. The club was organized in 1865 and its home was considered the most commodious and most beautiful club house in the world.
About 1897.
August Loeffler.
P. L. Sperr Collection.

708578f.text:
Fifth and 34th Street, northeast corner showing the former residence of A.Y. Stewart, now used as the Manhattan Club, to be later replaced by Altmans a large department store.
N.B.R.  1900.
Neg.~2177

708577f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, north from West 34th Street (left) showing prominently the Alexander T. Stewart mansion at the N.W. corner. This subsequently became the Manhattan Club and early in the twentieth century was demolished. Originally the site was occupied by the "Sarsaparilla"
Thompson home.
The structure indicated with an (X) was formerly the Caswell house which later became the home of the University Club. After being remodelled (1887) in the Queen Anne style it housed the present New York Club.
Separating these two club structures is the 2-story Avery Gallery. To the right margin appears a portion of the Brick Presbyterian Church at the N.W.
corner of 37th Street.
Circa 1900
Ewing Galloway
Neg. # 853

708566f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, north across West 34th Street. At the left margin is a portion of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. Opposite same is the distinctive Knickerbocker Trust Co. bldg. This is at the N. W. corner of 34th Street and was erected on the former A. T. Stewart home site.. The crosstown street-cars
are on 34th Street.
About 1910
Underhill, photographer
Gift of Urbrock Collection

731274f-a.title: Celebrations - Parades - Municipal events - Police Parade.
731274f-a.text:
Celebrations - Parades - Municipal Events: A set of 3 views of an unknown occasion : photographed on Fifth Ave. at 34th Street and showing the columned building of B. Altman and Co. for a background. The banners bearing the letters W.S.S. undoubtly mean War Savings Stamps and if so, signify a period between 1917-1918. The photographer gives another date. Views 1 and 2 are of the Police Department, while 3 is of the Fire Department. The intersection shown is East 35th Street.
19197
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.

demolition.
May 30, 1929.

712161f-a.text:
(1)
34th Street, south side, from Fifth to Seventh Avenues, showing the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria (shortly to be demolished) at Fifth Avenue, and the Hotel McAlpin at the S.E. corner of Sixth.
May 12, 1929.
Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
(2)
The same, another view not quite including the corner of the
Walcorf-Astoria.
May 30, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.

708570f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, at 34th Street, showing traffic towers which were shortly afterwards removed from Fifth Avenue because of traffic congestion.

Note shadow of old Waldorf Astoria Hotel at right of picture. A portion of the Waldorf may be seen at the left.

The building at the right, designed by Stanford White, was originally four stories in height. It was later converted into a fourteen story office building.

March 10, 1929
P.L. Sperr Photographer

712151f-a.text:
1, 3-9, 11 West 34th Street, adjoining and west of Fifth Avenue. No. 3-9 is the store of James MoCreery &. Company.
February 11, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712152f-a.text:
1-39 West 34th Street, at, adjoining, and west of the N.W. corner of Fifth Avenue, seen across the clearing on the south side, which exposes the wine cellars of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.
February 11, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712153f-a.text:
3-45 West 34th Street, north side, west of Fifth Avenue, seen across the Waldorf-Astoria clearing on the south side. No. 3-9 is
the store of James McCreery & Company.
February 11, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712156f-a.text:
11, 13-15, 17-19, 21-23, 25-27 West 34th Street, north side, we of Fifth Avenue, across the clearing on the south side.
February 11, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712154f-a.text:
34th Street, north side, east from and including Fifth Avenue, aerial view across Fifth Avenue from the south side east of Sixth Avenue. In the foreground the Waldorf-Astoria clearing is being excavated for the construction of the Empire State
Building.
February 10, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712155f-a.text:
34th Street, at and adjoining the N.W. conner of Fifth Avenue, including No. 3-9 West, the James McCreery & Company store. No. 1, in the center, was originally the Century Building. A detail of the Waldorf-Astoria clearing, aojoining the S.W. corner,
is shown in the foreground.
February 11, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712158f-a.text:
34th Street, north side, east from 19 West, west of Fifth Avenue, an aerial view, showing the clearing at the S.W. corner of Fifth
Avenue.
February 10, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712158f-b.text:
34th Street, north side, east from 19 West, west of Fifth Avenue, an aerial view, showing the clearing at the S.W. corner of Fifth
Avenue.
February 10, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

712159f-a.text:
34th Street, north side, from Fifth to Sixth Avenues, across the clearing on the south side at and adjoining Fifth Avenue, where
the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria has been demolished.
February 11, 1930.
P. L. Sperr.

708598f-a.text:
North on Fifth Avenue from B.Altman's Department Store,
34th to 35th Streets.
February 11, 1930.
P.L.Sperr, Photographer.

1557872.title: 350 Fifth Avenue - West 34th Street
1557872.folder: 350 Fifth Avenue - West 34th Street, Manhattan, NY

712160f-a.text:
W. 34th Street, south side, between Fifth and Sixth Avenues and viewed in a westward direction. Under renovation is the building occupied by "Spears", a furniture house which adjoins the Empire State Building (left). To the right appears the lower easterly side of the
Hotel McAlpin at Broadway.
August 1937.
0ift of Geo. D. Chinn.

712162f-a.text:
3O-32 West 34th Street, south side, between Fifth Ave., and Broadway, showing the demolition of the structure that housed the Berlits School of
Languages.
May 6, 1937.
P. L. Sperr.

708509f-a.text:
(1)
Fifth Avenue, east side (buildings thereupon), at E. 34th Street (center intersection). The photographer is viewing northeastward across the Empire State Building site, from a point to the west of the Avenue on W. 33rd Street. Occupyin2 the 34th-35th Street frontage is B. Altman's department store. Across the roof of same appears the upper portion of the Combustion Engineering Building on Madison Avenue. In the loft
background is the Lincoln Building.
P. L. Sperr  February 11, 1930
(2)
Another view of the same intersection, taken at an earlier date. The farther building is the B. Altman & Co. department store; the buildings in the foreground are at he southeast corner of the intersectfon. This view is notable for the distinctness of the ornamentation around the Altmen building. The columns are in the Ionic order of classical Greek architecture.
Wilberforce Eames Collection 1916

708567f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, north from 34th Street
Knickerbocker Trust building, with white columns, in foreground. This was originally designed by Stanford White, but
has since been made into a tall building.
1907
Brown Brothers, Photographers.

708574f-a.text: Home of Nrs. William Astor, south-west corner of Fifth Avenue and 34th Street, 1883, just before the old Waldorf Astoria took its place. "Please credit to Museum of the Cty ofNew York."

708575f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, at the S. W. corner of West 34th Street, showing the remaining Astor home outlined against the Hotel Waldorf. The latter stands on the site of the other of these twin houses. The remaining dwelling is to go the same way, providing the site for the second half of the combined Hotel Waldorf-Astoria. In time, the Empire State Building will succeed these.
Betw. 1893-98
Gift of Urbrock Collection

708576f-a.text:
Fifth Avenue, west side, at W. 34th Street, showing at the S. W. and N. W. corners respectively the Astor and Stewart homes. The former is shortly to be removed for the second half of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel. The latter is the home of the Manhettan Club at this date. At the left is a portion of the Hotel Waldorf
that was opened in 1893.
About 1898
Gift of Urbrock Collection
South West corner 34th St. and 5th Ave.
JJ Astor Res. 34th and 5th Ave.

the second half of the Waldorf-Astoria,

New York City

[1875?]
